Android phones by Samsung have been among the best in their class for well over a decade, offering an amalgam of thoughtful design, reliable hardware, and performance to match. Samsung was also the first smartphone maker to offer a mainstream foldable smartphone with the introduction of the Galaxy Z Fold more than half a decade ago. The tech giant kicked off 2025 by unveiling the Galaxy S25 series of smartphones . The Galaxy S25, Galaxy S25+, and Galaxy S25 Ultra bring a host of upgrades, along with more advanced AI-powered experiences, developed in partnership with Google. The latest Galaxy phones have Google's Gemini AI assistant, which is also on board the latest Pixel phones, enabled by default. With Spring 2025 well underway and after giving us a tiny glimpse of it at the S25 unveiling, Samsung added the Galaxy S25 Edge to its lineup of top-shelf phones. The new release stands out with a stunningly slim design. Its unique looks make all other big phones look bulky in comparison. As an industry leader in the Android realm for many years, the Galaxy S lineup should always be on your radar of Samsung upgrade options. If you're looking for value, the Galaxy A Series phones get you instantly recognizable looks and hardware features — especially an AMOLED display — at a much lower price point. On the other hand, the Galaxy Z Series of foldable phones offer cutting-edge design and unmatched versatility with a high-end price tag to match. Expect a vibrant AMOLED display (or two) with millions of individually backlit pixels, a speedy chipset, a versatile multi-sensor camera setup,  fast wired and wireless charging, and stereo speakers. You’ll also get future-proof wireless connectivity features such as 5G, Wi-Fi 6/6E/7, and Bluetooth 5.0 (and higher). The prices listed are for unlocked, contract-free smartphones. That’s a great option to buy if you are a frequent upgrader or purchasing the phone as a gift. You can also, of course, opt to pay for any phone in small monthly installments, either from Samsung or through the wireless carrier of your choice. What to Consider Form Factor With the latest Galaxy Z Flip and Z Fold iterations, Samsung transformed its foldable smartphones from expensive niche offerings to legit mainstream contenders. Therefore, they’re now worth considering before buying a Galaxy phone. Compared to standard rectangular slabs, foldable Galaxy phones offer vastly superior portability and multitasking chops. The Galaxy Z Flip is super pocketable, while the bulkier Galaxy Z Fold can replace a phone and a tablet in one. Due to their innovative design and more elaborate engineering, the Galaxy Z products are pricier than a standard high-end Samsung phone. Durability In addition to being pricier, the foldable Galaxy Z smartphones lack the durability of their mainstream siblings, which have an IP rating for water and dust resistance. For comparison, the Galaxy Z Series phones have a lower durability rating. The intricate hinges of their foldable screens rely on moving parts, so sealing the products against prolonged exposure to water and dust is more challenging. Traditional Galaxy phones are also more likely to survive accidental drops with or without a protective case — so if you have a bad habit of frequently dropping your phone, you should keep this in mind. I highly recommend purchasing a case for a foldable Galaxy because its build is more complicated and less likely to withstand heavy tumbles.   3. The 6 Best Samsung Phones of 2025: A Guide to the Latest Galaxy Models

The 6 Best Samsung Phones of 2025: A Guide to the Latest Galaxy Models

We’re breaking down the entire Galaxy lineup.

By Stefan VazharovUpdated: Feb 11, 2025 4:51 PM EST

If you buy something from the links on this page, we may earn a commission. Why Trust Us?

Android phones by Samsung have been among the best in their class for well over a decade, offering an amalgam of thoughtful design, reliable hardware, and performance to match. Samsung was also the first smartphone maker to offer a mainstream foldable smartphone with the introduction of the Galaxy Z Fold more than half a decade ago.

The tech giant kicked off 2025 by unveiling the Galaxy S25 series of smartphones. The Galaxy S25, Galaxy S25+, and Galaxy S25 Ultra bring a host of upgrades, along with more advanced AI-powered experiences, developed in partnership with Google. The latest Galaxy phones have Google's Gemini AI assistant, which is also on board the latest Pixel phones, enabled by default. From enhanced communication and Google search capabilities to next-level camera performance and image editing, AI will have a hand in many tasks and interactions with your new phone.

With Spring 2025 well underway and after giving us a tiny glimpse of it at the S25 unveiling, Samsung added the Galaxy S25 Edge to its lineup of top-shelf phones. The new release stands out with a stunningly slim design. Its unique looks make all other big phones look bulky in comparison.

As an industry leader in the Android realm for many years, the Galaxy S lineup should always be on your radar of Samsung upgrade options. If you're looking for value, the Galaxy A Series phones get you instantly recognizable looks and hardware features — especially an AMOLED display — at a much lower price point. On the other hand, the Galaxy Z Series of foldable phones offer cutting-edge design and unmatched versatility with a high-end price tag to match.

The Best Samsung Phones

  • Best Overall: Samsung Galaxy S25 Ultra
  • Best Value: Samsung Galaxy S24 FE 5G
  • Most Elegant: Samsung Galaxy S25 Edge
  • Best Under $1,000: Samsung Galaxy S25
  • Best Foldable: Samsung Galaxy Z Flip6

    All top-shelf smartphones from Samsung have a waterproof design and other essential features. Expect a vibrant AMOLED display (or two) with millions of individually backlit pixels, a speedy chipset, a versatile multi-sensor camera setup, fast wired and wireless charging, and stereo speakers. You’ll also get future-proof wireless connectivity features such as 5G, Wi-Fi 6/6E/7, and Bluetooth 5.0 (and higher).

    The prices listed are for unlocked, contract-free smartphones. That’s a great option to buy if you are a frequent upgrader or purchasing the phone as a gift. You can also, of course, opt to pay for any phone in small monthly installments, either from Samsung or through the wireless carrier of your choice.

    What to Consider

    Form Factor

    With the latest Galaxy Z Flip and Z Fold iterations, Samsung transformed its foldable smartphones from expensive niche offerings to legit mainstream contenders. Therefore, they’re now worth considering before buying a Galaxy phone.

    Compared to standard rectangular slabs, foldable Galaxy phones offer vastly superior portability and multitasking chops. The Galaxy Z Flip is super pocketable, while the bulkier Galaxy Z Fold can replace a phone and a tablet in one. Due to their innovative design and more elaborate engineering, the Galaxy Z products are pricier than a standard high-end Samsung phone.

    Durability

    In addition to being pricier, the foldable Galaxy Z smartphones lack the durability of their mainstream siblings, which have an IP rating for water and dust resistance. For comparison, the Galaxy Z Series phones have a lower durability rating. The intricate hinges of their foldable screens rely on moving parts, so sealing the products against prolonged exposure to water and dust is more challenging.

    Traditional Galaxy phones are also more likely to survive accidental drops with or without a protective case — so if you have a bad habit of frequently dropping your phone, you should keep this in mind. I highly recommend purchasing a case for a foldable Galaxy because its build is more complicated and less likely to withstand heavy tumbles.

    Camera

    Even though they’re on another level when it comes to multitasking and entertainment capabilities brought by their shape-shifting primary screens, Samsung’s foldable phones don’t have the camera prowess of the top-shelf Galaxy S handsets. This is entirely a matter of packaging and space — incorporating a foldable display inside the phone leaves less space for camera sensors and zoom lenses.

    If camera quality is paramount to you, consider a Galaxy with an Ultra moniker. These phones always pack the best camera tech of any Galaxy. The newly launched Samsung Galaxy S25 Edge has the same primary camera, but it lacks a telephoto unit. It's a great buy for those who don't prioritize zoom capabilities.

    Memory

    The more RAM a Samsung Galaxy phone has, the better it is at multitasking — so if you plan on constantly toggling between many open apps, you should consider a phone with 8GB or more.

    Regarding onboard storage, if you plan to capture many photos and videos with your Galaxy’s (consistently stellar for the money) camera, consider getting a version with more storage than the 128-GB entry-level models provide. Most Samsung phones don’t have memory card slots for easy expansion, so spending another $50 to $100 upfront is worth it. Depending on your needs and budget, you can spec high-end Galaxy phones with up to 1 TB of storage.

    How I Tested

    I've been testing smartphones for years, including Samsung's Galaxy lineup. When new products launch, I put them through their paces as my primary phones for weeks to evaluate their design, hardware, performance, and battery life in comparison to older models. I also pay close attention to the overall value they deliver.

    This Samsung Galaxy guide contains my carefully scrutinized picks with the most up-to-date specs and features in their price categories — from affordable to high-end — ensuring that your new phone keeps you satisfied for a long time. I also included older iterations, which come at a slightly lower price point, that are still worthy and perfectly capable if you don’t need the latest bells and whistles. But I always recommend spending a bit more to get the current generation if you’re on the fence; the design and hardware improvements you’ll get are worth it.

    1
    Best Overall

    Samsung Galaxy S25 Ultra Smartphone

    $1,249 at Amazon
    $1,300 $1,100 at Best Buy

    Pros

    • Beautiful design and top-tier hardware
    • Fantastic camera
    • Amazing display and integrated S Pen stylus

    Cons

    • S Pen lacks the previous generations' Bluetooth connectivity

    The S25 Ultra is the Samsung Galaxy phone to get if you want the latest and greatest in hardware specs and camera performance—if it fits your budget. It has a bigger, sharper screen, a distinctive design, and a more premium build with titanium and Corning Gorilla Armor 2 glass ceramic screen cover. There's also a larger battery and a vastly superior camera setup than its Galaxy S25 and S25+ siblings. This all comes while packing the same cutting-edge silicon and supporting the full set of AI features. The Ultra is always the most powerful Galaxy with the best camera.

    Impressively, the Galaxy S25 Ultra is lighter than the S24 Ultra it replaces, even though it has a bigger screen and the same battery capacity. By going for slimmer display bezels and more rounded corners, Samsung made the new Ultra more pocket-friendly despite its larger display.

    As always, the Ultra's integrated S Pen stylus sets it apart from the rest of the Galaxy S25 family. This makes the big-screen phone capable of creative and productivity tasks that competitors can't match. I constantly relied on the stylus to take notes during meetings and to unwind with digital coloring books. However, it's worth noting the S Pen doesn't have Bluetooth connectivity like in past Ultra iterations.

    Again, the Ultra's camera hardware includes a high-resolution 200-megapixel wide sensor and sharp telephoto and ultra-wide units. The primary camera has the highest resolution in the business. Combined with the 50-megapixel telephoto camera and ultra-wide units, this makes the device a solid contender for the best camera phone of 2025. Unlike a bulky DSLR camera and its swappable optics, its many camera sensors and lenses with various focal lengths were always at my disposal. I liked having instant access to such a versatile setup.

    You can snag the Samsung Galaxy S25 Ultra in titanium black, titanium gray, and titanium silverblue. Additional color options are also available exclusively from Samsung.

    Key Specs

    ChipQualcomm Snapdragon 8 Elite
    Display6.9-inch QHD+ Dynamic AMOLED 2X display with 120 Hz maximum refresh rate
    Camera200MP main, dual telephoto (10MP and 50MP) with 3 and 5x magnification optical zoom, 50MP ultra-wide; 12MP selfie camera
    Memory12/16GB of RAM, up to 1TB of storage
    Other5,000 mAh battery, IP68 waterproof
    2
    Best Value

    Samsung Galaxy S24 FE Smartphone

    Now 19% Off
    $650 $525 at Amazon
    $650 at Walmart$650 $500 at Best Buy

    Pros

    • Great specs for the money
    • As durable as the standard S24
    • Plenty of color options

    Cons

    • Telephoto and ultra-wide cameras could use an upgrade

    Like its predecessor, the Samsung Galaxy S24 FE (Fan Edition) delivers top-tier specs and performance at an incredibly agreeable price point. For less than $650 before additional deals and discounts, the value-packed Galaxy offers everything a great big-screen Android should have: sleek design, tough build, and excellent hardware specs.

    Best of all, the new FE offers full support of the Galaxy AI suite of tools, ensuring it can deliver a similar user experience as its pricier relatives. Compared to the outgoing Galaxy S23 FE, the sequel also has a bigger screen and battery, as well as a beefier Exynos chip. Its camera setup has remained the same, however.

    I spent a couple of weeks with the S24 FE as my go-to Android and never felt like I was lacking in ergonomics, tactility, and everyday performance. Save for the camera, the experience was close to the one offered by costlier Galaxy S versions. The phone is a great buy overall.

    Key Specs

    ChipExynos 2400e
    Display6.7-inch FHD+ Dynamic AMOLED 2X display with 120 Hz maximum refresh rate
    CameraTriple camera with 50MP main, 8MP telephoto, 12MP ultra-wide; 10MP selfie camera
    Memory8GB of RAM, up to 256GB of storage
    Other4,700 mAh battery, IP 68 waterproof
    Advertisement - Continue Reading Below
    3
    Best Galaxy Under $1,000

    Samsung Galaxy S25 Smartphone

    Now 10% Off
    $800 $719 at Amazon
    $800 $700 at Best Buy

    Pros

    • Top-tier hardware specs
    • Sleek and durable
    • Reasonably priced

    Cons

    • Camera could use a deeper zoom

    The Samsung Galaxy S25 is the best option for buyers on a sub-$1,000 budget. Available in several colors, it has an elegant design, a powerful chip, a capable camera setup, and a beautiful AMOLED display. Metaphorically speaking, the Samsung Galaxy S is the iPhone of the Android realm—a product with a long track record of excellence that's equally great for first-time users and Galaxy faithful.

    Starting at a penny below $800 before additional discounts, the product has an agreeable price despite its top-tier specs. And thanks to a 6.2-inch screen, the Galaxy S25 is incredibly compact by today's premium Android phone standards. Its size gave me the luxury of cranking out messages on the move without worrying about dropping it. If you want a top-shelf device that ticks all the boxes and is easy to use with one hand, this is your best option.

    Design-wise, the Galaxy S25 looks almost completely identical to its predecessor. Save for the slightly thicker rings around the newcomer's rear cameras and the different colors, it's hard to tell the two iterations apart. You can order the product in Icyblue, mint, navy, and silver shadow colors. Samsung's online store also offers exclusive shades dubbed blueblack, pinkgold, and coralred.

    On the hardware side, the S25 packs a beefier Qualcomm Snapdragon Elite chip with a more advanced 3-nanometer architecture than the outgoing model. Combined with 12 GB of RAM and the superior multitasking capabilities it brings (the starter S24 had 8 GB of RAM for comparison), as well as more advanced Wi-Fi 7 and Bluetooth 5.4 connectivity, the new generation is even more futureproof. It performed admirably when I put it through its paces, consistently treating me to instant OS and AI interactions, speedy multitasking, and smooth gameplay.

    If you need a bigger screen, larger battery, and faster charging speeds, consider the $200 pricier Galaxy S25+ instead. It has a higher-resolution display panel, double the storage capacity in entry-level guise (256 GB vs. 128 GB in the Galaxy S25), and a bigger battery than the non-plus Galaxy S. The rest of its hardware specs are identical. After extensively testing both variants, I found myself reaching for the bigger-screen version more frequently for gaming and streaming video.

    Key Specs

    ChipQualcomm Snapdragon 8 Elite
    Display6.2-inch FHD+ Dynamic AMOLED 2X display with 120 Hz maximum refresh rate
    Camera50MP main, 10MP telephoto, 12MP ultra-wide; 12MP selfie camera
    Memory12GB of RAM, 128/256GB of storage
    Other4,000 mAh battery, IP68 waterproof
    4
    Best Foldable

    Samsung Galaxy Z Flip6 Smartphone

    $1,100 at Amazon
    $1,920 at Samsung$1,100 at Best Buy

    Pros

    • Sleek and durable
    • Futureproof hardware and performance
    • Seven years' worth of updates

    Cons

    • Could use a zoom camera

    The Galaxy Z Flip6 is a more futuristic and pocket-friendly alternative to today's best smartphones and an exciting follow-up to one of the best foldable phones on the market. Compared to the Galaxy Z Flip5, the new iteration has a more refined design with characterful camera ring accents, a stronger hinge, a higher durability rating, a beefier chip, a higher-resolution main camera, and 50 percent more RAM for improved multitasking.

    Dubbed Flex Window, the big external display of the Z Flip6 brings more interactive widgets and more elaborate customization options. Predictably, its ample size also makes answering texts easy because it can display a full keyboard. You'll be able to answer messages and keep tabs on important notifications, among other crucial tasks, without having to open the phone.

    I constantly relied on the functionality when I used the Z Flip6 as my primary phone. Having access to essential features without having to flip the phone open allowed me to take a welcome break from big rectangular slabs.

    Like in the outgoing Z Flip5, the bigger external screen of the sequel makes capturing selfies with the dual camera even more effortless. And because of its unique form, the Z Flip6 offers an equally fun user experience for many common tasks. Some of the noteworthy highlights include the ability to split an app's interface and place its controls on the bottom half of the display or record video like an old-school camcorder while partially unfolded, to name a couple.

    Samsung offers the Galaxy Z Flip6 in several colors: blue, mint, yellow, and Silver Shadow. You can spec the device with 256 or 512GB of onboard storage.

    Key Specs

    ChipQualcomm Snapdragon 8 Gen 3
    Display6.7-inch folding Full HD+ Dynamic AMOLED2X with 120 Hz refresh rate, 3.4-inch external Super AMOLED
    Camera50MP main, 12MP wide-angle; 10MP selfie camera
    Memory12GB of RAM, up to 512GB of storage
    Other4,000 mAh battery, IP48 water- and dust-resistant
    Advertisement - Continue Reading Below
    5
    Most Elegant

    Samsung Samsung Galaxy S25 Edge Smartphone

    $1,100 at Amazon

    Pros

    • Stunningly thin yet incredlibly tough
    • Excellent all-around performance
    • Superb primary camera

    Cons

    • No telephoto camera

    The Galaxy S25 Edge is Samsung’s thinnest, most elegant smartphone yet, and a proper product to revive the “Edge” moniker. The latter was last used in the Samsung Galaxy S7 Edge, which was released almost a decade ago. Measuring only 5.8 millimeters in thickness, the latest addition to the Galaxy S25 lineup pushes the boundaries of conventional smartphone design in a truly impressive fashion. And thanks to a titanium frame and ceramic glass covers, the gadget is as tough as it is slim.

    Having such a thin and light build makes the Galaxy S25 Edge surprisingly easy to operate with one hand, especially considering its 6.7-inch display panel. Big-screen phones are usually much unwieldier, so being able to type messages, scroll through webpages and social media feeds, and switch between multiple apps without straining my wrist felt super refreshing.

    Hardware-wise, the Galaxy S25 Edge offers a curious mashup between Galaxy S25+ and Galaxy S25 Ultra bits. The former shares a display panel with the Edge, while the latter has the same high-resolution primary camera. The 200-megapixel unit is one of the best in the business. A telephoto camera is missing in the Edge, but given its unique looks, living with only two rear cameras is an acceptable tradeoff.

    Performance-wise, the Edge is on par with the rest of the Galaxy S25 lineup. Despite being a tad smaller than the S25’s unit, the latest iteration’s battery easily got me through a day of use.

    I’d recommend the Galaxy S25 Edge over a currently discounted Galaxy S25 Ultra or a cheaper Galaxy S25+ for its captivating design and next-level ergonomics. If those are not a priority, you’ll get more hardware and features for your money. The phone starts at $1,099.99 for a variant with 256 GB of storage.

    Key Specs

    ChipQualcomm Snapdragon 8 Elite
    Display6.7-inch QHD+ Dynamic AMOLED 2X, 120 Hz refresh rate
    Camera200MP main, 12MP ultra-wide, 8K video recording, 12MP selfie camera
    Memory12GB of RAM, 256/512GB of storage
    Other3,900 mAh battery, IP68 waterproof
    6
    The Ultimate Foldable Galaxy

    Samsung Galaxy Z Fold6 Smartphone

    €1,900 at Samsung

    Pros

    • Replaces a phone and a tablet
    • Fantastic triple camera
    • Excellent everyday performance and battery life
    • Seven years' worth of updates

    Cons

    • S Pen costs extra

    Following the tradition set by its predecessors, Samsung’s Galaxy Z Fold6 is the tech giant’s most avant-garde and expensive smartphone. It's more attention-commanding and versatile than any other Galaxy because it can transform from a phone to a tablet in an instant. The quality and versatility of its unique folding form factor make the product well worth its hefty price tag. With the Fold6 as my go-to phone, I decluttered my gear bag by leaving a tablet I always carry out.

    Compared to the Galaxy Z Fold5 it replaces, the Fold6 has a sleeker design with sharper corners, a more powerful chip, and a bigger external display whose new ratio makes it comfier to use. The phone also packs a tougher foldable screen hinge with superior impact absorption capabilities.

    In addition, its IP48 durability rating ensures that the Z Fold6 has been tested to resist exposure to solid particles. That’s a big deal, as the previous Folds were only water-resistant.

    Of course, Samsung also equipped the Z Fold6 with a fantastic triple camera, whose primary image sensor resolution and optical zoom capabilities are on par with those of a non-Ultra Galaxy S snapper. Its selfie cameras feature a sensor hidden underneath the foldable display, though I’d only use that one for video calls.

    The range-topping Samsung Galaxy supports the S Pen stylus, as usual. You can order it with up to 1TB of onboard storage in pink, navy, and Silver Shadow color options. Samsung’s online store also offers two exclusive black and white colors.

    Key Specs

    ChipQualcomm Snapdragon 8 Gen 3
    Display7.6-inch folding QXGA+ Dynamic AMOLED 2X, 6.3-inch HD+ Dynamic AMOLED 2X, 120 Hz maximum refresh rate
    Camera50MP wide, 10MP telephoto, 12MP ultra-wide; 10MP selfie camera, 4MP under-display camera
    Memory12GB of RAM, up to 1TB of storage
    Other4,400 mAh battery, IP48 water- and dust-resistant
    Stefan Vazharov
    Senior Technology Editor, Reviews

    Stefan is an award-winning consumer technology editor with over a decade of experience in reviewing gadgets, particularly smartphones, tablets, smartwatches, desktop and laptop computers across multiple form factors and platforms, as well as accessories for them. He also covers televisions and audio equipment, including headphones, earbuds, wireless speakers, and soundbars. Since joining Hearst in 2015, Stefan has contributed to BestProducts, Popular Mechanics, and numerous other publications. Prior to his current role, he served as the US Editor for GSMArena.com.
